name: Asus Tinker Board S (EXPERIMENTAL)

postProvisioning: The device is performing a shutdown. Please wait until all LEDs are off.
Remove the balenaOS installation media.

Before powering up the Asus Tinker Board S, make sure that the jumper between the 5V power supply and the HDMI connector is in the parking (no function) mode, as ilustrated in this link https://tinkerboarding.co.uk/wiki/index.php/Setup
Remove and re-connect power to the board.

instructions: Write the OS file you downloaded to your SD card. We recommend using Etcher.
Insert the freshly burnt SD card into the Asus Tinker Board S.
Warning! This will also completely erase internal storage media, so please make a backup first.

Before powering up the Asus Tinker Board S, make sure that the jumper between the 5V power supply and the HDMI connector is in the MASKROM mode, as ilustrated in this link https://tinkerboarding.co.uk/wiki/index.php/Setup
The device is performing a shutdown. Please wait until all LEDs are off.
Remove the balenaOS installation media.

Before powering up the Asus Tinker Board S, make sure that the jumper between the 5V power supply and the HDMI connector is in the parking (no function) mode, as ilustrated in this link https://tinkerboarding.co.uk/wiki/index.php/Setup
Remove and re-connect power to the board.

name: RushUp Kitra 520 (DISCONTINUED)

postProvisioning: The device has performed a shutdown. Press the power switch PWR SW to the off position.
Remove the resinOS installation media.
Remove the Artik520 module from the evaluation carrier and plug it on the Kitra520 carrier.
Press and hold the power button PB1 - PB2 until you hear a double buzz sound.

instructions: Write the OS file you downloaded to your SD card. We recommend using Etcher.
Insert the freshly burnt SD card into the RushUp Kitra 520.
Warning! This will also completely erase internal storage media, so please make a backup first.
Set SW2 dip switch to position 1:on, 2:on.  Also, make sure jumpers J20 and J33 are set towards the edge of the board.
Press and hold the power button PB1 - PB2 until you hear a double buzz sound.
The device has performed a shutdown. Press the power switch PWR SW to the off position.
Remove the resinOS installation media.
Remove the Artik520 module from the evaluation carrier and plug it on the Kitra520 carrier.
Press and hold the power button PB1 - PB2 until you hear a double buzz sound.

name: Generic AARCH64 (ARMv8) (EXPERIMENTAL)
instructions: Download/pull the following docker image on the target machine: {{ dockerImage }} .
Download the configuration file and deploy it on target.

Run the resinOS container using resinos-in-container. This tool/script will reference the image and the configuration file (downloaded above) as command line arguments. Example: ./resinos-in-container.sh --config ./config.json --image {{ dockerImage }}. Tweak the --config argument based on the filename set for the downloaded configuration file.

name: QEMU X86 32bit (EXPERIMENTAL)
instructions:
Run the following to start the image:
On systems with KVM support:
qemu-system-i386 -drive file=resin-image-qemux86.img,media=disk,cache=none,format=raw -net nic,model=virtio -net user -m 512 -nographic -machine type=pc,accel=kvm -smp 4 -cpu host
On systems without KVM support:
qemu-system-i386 -drive file=resin-image-qemux86.img,media=disk,cache=none,format=raw -net nic,model=virtio -net user -m 512 -nographic -machine type=pc -smp 4
Tweak -smp and -cpu parameters based on the CPU of the machine qemu is running on. -cpu parameter needs to be dropped on OSX and Windows.
Tweak -nographic and -m 512 to set the display of qemu and memory respectively.

windows: Install Windows drivers for Edison from here
Unplug the Intel Edison board from your system.
Unzip the downloaded Device OS file.

Open a terminal with administrative privileges and execute the following from the unzipped directory:
flashall.bat

Plug the Intel Edison as per the instructions on your terminal.
You can check the progress of the provisioning on your terminal.
osx:
You need MacPorts installed on your system.
Run the following to install dfu-util, usbutils and coreutils: sudo port install dfu-util usbutils coreutils && sudo port activate dfu-util
Unplug the Intel Edison board from your system.
Unzip the downloaded Device OS file.

Execute the following from the unzipped directory:
sudo ./flashall.sh
If you have trouble executing, you may need to modify the file permissions first:
sudo chmod +x ./flashall.sh

Plug the Intel Edison as per the instructions on your terminal.
You can check the progress of the provisioning on your terminal.
linux:
Install dfu-util and coreutils from your distributions repos. For example, for Ubuntu:
apt-get install dfu-util coreutils
Unplug the Intel Edison board from your system.
Unzip the downloaded Device OS file.

Execute the following from the unzipped directory:
sudo ./flashall.sh
If you have trouble executing, you may need to modify the file permissions first:
sudo chmod +x ./flashall.sh

Plug the Intel Edison as per the instructions on your terminal.
You can check the progress of the provisioning on your terminal.

osx.name: greadlink
osx.instructions:
This utility is included in the `coreutils` package. Run:

	$ sudo port install coreutils

Or with Homebrew:

	$ brew install coreutils

osx.name: dfu-util
osx.instructions:
Install dfu-util by running:

	$ sudo port install dfu-util@0.7

Or with Homebrew:

	$ brew install dfu-util

linux.name: readlink
linux.instructions:
Install `coreutils` from your distribution repos. For example, for Ubuntu:

	$ sudo apt-get install coreutils

linux.name: dfu-util
linux.instructions:
Install `dfu-util` from your distribution repos. For example, for Ubuntu:

	$ sudo apt-get install dfu-util

win32.name: dfu-util
win32.instructions:
Install Windows drivers for Edison from:

	http://downloadmirror.intel.com/24909/eng/IntelEdisonDriverSetup1.2.1.exe

windows:
Install Win32 Disk Imager.
Start Win32 Disk Imager and navigate to the Device OS .img in your downloads. Select <OS-image-download>.img (but replacing <OS-image-download> with your download name) as your Image File.'
Insert your SD card. In Win32 Disk Imager, select your SD card in the drop down for Device
Make 100% sure it is the correct drive and click Write.
Warning!: Please make sure you have backed-up your SD card first, as this will completely erase the contents of your SD card.
Wait until it's finished writing.
Safely eject the freshly burnt SD card and insert into the Technologic TS-7700.
Connect your Technologic TS-7700 to the internet, then power it up.
osx: Plug your SD card into your computer and in a terminal run diskutil list. You should see your SD card as /dev/diskN, (N=1,2,3,4)
Unmount your SD card with diskutil umountDisk /dev/diskN where N is your SD card number.

Run sudo dd bs=1m if=~/Downloads/<OS-image-download>.img of=/dev/rdiskN but replacing <OS-image-download> with your download name and replacing the of=/dev/rdiskN with the appropriate device name.
Warning! Please make sure you have backed-up your SD card first, as this will completely erase its contents. You can see a full description of this process here.
Safely eject the freshly burnt SD card and insert into the Technologic TS-7700.
Connect your Technologic TS-7700 to the internet, then power it up.
linux:
Run df -h to see what devices are currently mounted.
Insert your SD card.
Run df -h again,the device that wasn't there last time is your SD card. It will be listed as something like /dev/mmcblk0p1 or /dev/sdd1. The last part ("p1" or "1" respectively) is the partition number, so the SD should be something like "/dev/mmcblk0" or "/dev/sdd"
Unmount your SD card with umount /dev/mmcblk0pN or umount /dev/sddN where N is your SD card number.

Run sudo dd bs=1m if=~/Downloads/<OS-image-download>.img of=/dev/rdiskN but replacing <OS-image-download> with your download name and replacing the of=/dev/rdiskN with the appropriate device name.
Warning! Please make sure you have backed-up your SD card first, as this will completely erase its contents. You can see a full description of this process here.
Safely eject the freshly burnt SD card and insert into the Technologic TS-7700.
Connect your Technologic TS-7700 to the internet, then power it up.

options.name: appUpdatePollInterval

name: QEMU X86 64bit (EXPERIMENTAL)
instructions:
Run the following to start the image:
On systems with KVM support:
qemu-system-x86_64 -drive file=resin-image-qemux86-64.img,media=disk,cache=none,format=raw -net nic,model=virtio -net user -m 512 -nographic -machine type=pc,accel=kvm -smp 4 -cpu host
On systems without KVM support:
qemu-system-x86_64 -drive file=resin-image-qemux86-64.img,media=disk,cache=none,format=raw -net nic,model=virtio -net user -m 512 -nographic -machine type=pc -smp 4
Tweak -smp and -cpu parameters based on the CPU of the machine qemu is running on. -cpu parameter needs to be dropped on OSX and Windows.
Tweak -nographic and -m 512 to set the display of qemu and memory respectively.

options.message: Check for updates every X minutes
options.name: appUpdatePollInterval

name: VIA VAB 820-quad (DISCONTINUED)

postProvisioning: The device is performing a shutdown. Please wait until the device is disconnected in the dashboard and disconnect the power cable.
Remove the resinOS installation media.
Set J11 (just next to the micro SD card slot) to position 1-2 (the position closest to the edge of the board).
Remove and re-connect power to the board.

instructions: Write the OS file you downloaded to an SD card. We recommend using Etcher.
Insert the freshly burnt SD card into the VIA VAB 820-quad.
Warning! This will also completely erase internal storage media, so please make a backup first.
Set J11 (just next to the micro SD card slot) to position 2-3 (the position furthest away from the edge of the board) and then power on the board.
The device is performing a shutdown. Please wait until the device is disconnected in the dashboard and disconnect the power cable.
Remove the resinOS installation media.
Set J11 (just next to the micro SD card slot) to position 1-2 (the position closest to the edge of the board).
Remove and re-connect power to the board.

name: Samsung Artik 520 (DISCONTINUED)

postProvisioning: The device has performed a shutdown. Press the power switch PWR SW to the off position.
Remove the resinOS installation media.
Set SW2 dip switch to position 1:off, 2:off.
Press the power switch PWR SW to the on position. Press and hold for 1 second the SW3 POWER push button.

instructions: Write the OS file you downloaded to your SD card. We recommend using Etcher.
Insert the freshly burnt SD card into the Samsung Artik 520.
Warning! This will also completely erase internal storage media, so please make a backup first.
Set SW2 dip switch to position 1:on, 2:on.  Also, make sure jumpers J20 and J33 are set towards the edge of the board.
Press the power switch PWR SW to the on position. Press and hold for 1 second the SW3 POWER push button.
The device has performed a shutdown. Press the power switch PWR SW to the off position.
Remove the resinOS installation media.
Set SW2 dip switch to position 1:off, 2:off.
Press the power switch PWR SW to the on position. Press and hold for 1 second the SW3 POWER push button.

options.message: Check for updates every X minutes
options.name: appUpdatePollInterval

name: Revolution Pi Core 3
instructions: While not having the Revolution Pi board powered, connect your system to the board's USB port via a micro-USB cable.
Power on the Revolution Pi board.
Write the OS to the internal MMC storage device. We recommend using Etcher.
When flashing is complete, power off the board and unplug the micro-USB cable.
Connect your Revolution Pi Core 3 to the internet, then power it up.

name: Intel NUC

postProvisioning: The device is performing a shutdown. Please wait until all LEDs are off.
Remove the balenaOS installation media.
Power on your device.

instructions: Write the OS file you downloaded to your USB key. We recommend using Etcher.
Insert the freshly burnt USB key into the Intel NUC.
Warning! This will also completely erase internal storage media, so please make a backup first.

Please make sure you do not have any other USB keys inserted.
Power up the Intel NUC. Make sure you have a keyboard connected.
Press the F10 key (may differ on some platforms) while BIOS is loading in order to enter the boot menu.
Next, select the name of your USB key.
The device is performing a shutdown. Please wait until all LEDs are off.
Remove the balenaOS installation media.
Power on your device.

instructions: Write the OS file you downloaded to your USB key. We recommend using Etcher.
Insert the freshly burnt USB key into the UP board.
Warning! This will also completely erase internal storage media, so please make a backup first.

Power up the UP board. Make sure you have a keyboard connected.

Remove the resinOS installation media.
Unplug and plug power on your UP board.

name: Balena Fin (CM3)
instructions: While not having the Fin board powered, connect your system to the board's DBG port via a micro-USB cable..
Power on the Fin by attaching power to either the Barrel or the Phoenix connector.
Write the OS to the internal MMC storage device. We recommend using Etcher.
When flashing is complete, power off the board by detaching the power and unplug the DGB micro-USB cable.
Connect your Balena Fin (CM3) to the internet, then power it up.
